title: Profit at fashion giant Zara's UK shops has halved this year as dividend is slashed
text:
Profit at fashion giant Zara's UK shops halved this year amid a troubled retail sector where a number of chains have collapsed.

Zara UK, which is owned by the world's biggest fashion group Inditex, reported a 10 per cent jump in sales from £704.8million to £772.5million, according to documents filed last week.

But its pre-tax profits for the year slumped from £51.8million to £22.3million.

The firm has 63 outlets in Britain where it also operates Massimo Dutti and Bershka.

It said its selling and distribution costs rose by 7 per cent as it opened and relocated stores. Bosses said Zara plans to open further shops here as opportunities arise.

Zara UK – which claims it can design, manufacture and deliver clothes to stores within 15 days – paid out a dividend of £17.5million compared with £41million the previous year.

The chain remains one of the high street's beacons despite its profit slump and is still regarded as a benchmark by rivals.

John Lewis said last month it made a loss in the first half of the year. On Friday, women's clothing chain Bonmarche was forced to call in administrators.
